metadata.name: Entity
title: Gcloud
Datastore
Entity
metadata.description:
Entity

Entity represents a Datastore record. Every Entity has a Key, and a list of properties.

examples.code:
entity = Gcloud::Datastore::Entity.new
entity.key = Gcloud::Datastore::Key.new "User", "heidi@example.com"
entity["name"] = "Heidi Henderson"

title: Gcloud
Datastore
Entity#[]
metadata.description: Retrieve a property value by providing the name.

examples.caption: Properties can be retrieved with a string name:
examples.code:
require "gcloud"

gcloud = Gcloud.new
dataset = gcloud.datastore
user = dataset.find "User", "heidi@example.com"
user["name"] #=> "Heidi Henderson"

examples.caption: Or with a symbol name:
examples.code:
require "gcloud"

gcloud = Gcloud.new
dataset = gcloud.datastore
user = dataset.find "User", "heidi@example.com"
user[:name] #=> "Heidi Henderson"

returns.description: Returns nil if the property doesn’t exist

examples.caption: Properties can be set with a string name:
examples.code:
require "gcloud"

gcloud = Gcloud.new
dataset = gcloud.datastore
user = dataset.find "User", "heidi@example.com"
user["name"] = "Heidi H. Henderson"

examples.caption: Or with a symbol name:
examples.code:
require "gcloud"

gcloud = Gcloud.new
dataset = gcloud.datastore
user = dataset.find "User", "heidi@example.com"
user[:name] = "Heidi H. Henderson"

metadata.name: properties
title: Gcloud
Datastore
Entity#properties
metadata.description: Retrieve properties in a hash-like structure. Properties can be accessed or set by string or symbol.

examples.code:
entity.properties[:name] = "Heidi H. Henderson"
entity.properties["name"] #=> "Heidi H. Henderson"

entity.properties.each do |name, value|
  puts "property #{name} has a value of #{value}"
end

examples.caption: A property’s existence can be determined by calling exist?:
examples.code:
entity.properties.exist? :name #=> true
entity.properties.exist? "name" #=> true
entity.properties.exist? :expiration #=> false

examples.caption: A property can be removed from the entity:
The properties can be converted to a hash:

metadata.name: key=
title: Gcloud
Datastore
Entity#key=
metadata.description:
Sets the Key that identifies the entity.

Once the entity is saved, the key is frozen and immutable. Trying to set a key when immutable will raise a RuntimeError.

examples.caption: The Key can be set before the entity is saved:
examples.code:
require "gcloud"

gcloud = Gcloud.new
dataset = gcloud.datastore
entity = Gcloud::Datastore::Entity.new
entity.key = Gcloud::Datastore::Key.new "User"
dataset.save entity

examples.caption: Once the entity is saved, the key is frozen and immutable:
examples.code:
require "gcloud"

gcloud = Gcloud.new
dataset = gcloud.datastore
entity = dataset.find "User", "heidi@example.com"
entity.persisted? #=> true
entity.key = Gcloud::Datastore::Key.new "User" #=> RuntimeError
entity.key.frozen? #=> true
entity.key.id = 9876543221 #=> RuntimeError

metadata.name: persisted?
title: Gcloud
Datastore
Entity#persisted?
metadata.description: Indicates if the record is persisted. Default is false.

examples.code:
require "gcloud"

gcloud = Gcloud.new
dataset = gcloud.datastore

new_entity = Gcloud::Datastore::Entity.new
new_entity.persisted? #=> false

found_entity = dataset.find "User", "heidi@example.com"
found_entity.persisted? #=> true

metadata.name: exclude_from_indexes?
title: Gcloud
Datastore
Entity#exclude_from_indexes?
metadata.description:
Indicates if a property is flagged to be excluded from the Datastore indexes. The default value is false. This is another way of saying that values are indexed by default.

If the property is multi-valued, each value in the list can be managed separately for exclusion from indexing. Calling this method for a multi-valued property will return an array that contains the excluded boolean value for each corresponding value in the property. For example, if a multi-valued property contains ["a", "b"], and only the value "b" is indexed (meaning that "a"’ is excluded), the return value for this method will be [true, false].

examples.caption: Single property values will return a single flag setting:
A multi-valued property will return an array of flag settings:

metadata.name: exclude_from_indexes!
title: Gcloud
Datastore
Entity#exclude_from_indexes!
metadata.description:
Sets whether a property should be excluded from the Datastore indexes. Setting true will exclude the property from the indexes. Setting false will include the property on any applicable indexes. The default value is false. This is another way of saying that values are indexed by default.

If the property is multi-valued, each value in the list can be managed separately for exclusion from indexing. When you call this method for a multi-valued property, you can pass either a single boolean argument to be applied to all of the values, or an array that contains the boolean argument for each corresponding value in the property. For example, if a multi-valued property contains ["a", "b"], and only the value "b" should be indexed (meaning that "a"’ should be excluded), you should pass the array: [true, false].

examples.caption: Multi-valued properties can be given multiple exclude flags:
Or, a single flag can be applied to all values in a property:
Flags can also be set with a block:
